features: Over 1,000 hospitals nationwide give newborns The Soothie pacifier
body.description: Philips Avent Soothie is the pacifier brand distributed in hospitals nationwide and used by doctors & nurses to soothe newborns. Its one-piece construction is specially sized and shaped for babies 0-3 months old and adheres to the American Academy of Pediatrics guidelines. Soothie is designed to calm and soothe without inhibiting normal oral development, like the natural development of teeth and gums. Transparent, tasteless, and odorless, the nipple is strong and smooth. It won't become sticky, discolored, or misshapen. Soothie is made of hospital-grade, BPA-free, and latex-free silicone for strength, comfort, and durability. It is dishwasher safe and can be sterilized in a sterilizer. Soon all of our Soothies will say Philips Avent; but for a while, you may see some products that say “Soothie, Children’s Medical Ventures” and others that say “Philips Avent” in the market. Both are real, authentic Philips Avent Soothies. The product meets CPSC safety requirements and the same high-quality standards you’ve come to expect from us.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on December 12, 2023
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars Little known product
reviews.reviewText: Got one at the hospital with our first. I liked it so much that I bought two for our second. The vanilla doesn’t last forever but it smells good AND I love the color of these. This color is unique to these scented/tasted ones.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on November 2, 2023
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars Will buy again
reviews.reviewText: I love these pacifiers they smell just like vanilla I will definitely buy again

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on May 12, 2021
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars Worked for me
reviews.reviewText: This is all my daughter would take because she used the jolly pop scented ones in the NICU. She is now five months and is almost weened off pacifiers but this really helped because I wanted her to take one. They told me in the NICU they give them to babies because it helps prevent SIDS and that was a huge concern for me since she had low oxygen and breathing problems. I couldn’t find the scented jolly pop so I used these instead and she took to them easily. She wouldn’t take the un scented ones for some reason. My baby was bottle fed so idk if it affects breastfeeding but after she stopped taking the premade formula bottles they give at the hospital (about 3 weeks after birth) she transitioned well to the avent bottles I guess the nipples are the same/similar. I know if babies take certain bottles they might want to take other pacifiers but anyways to sum up these worked for my NICU, formula fed, avent bottle baby lol.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on December 27, 2022
reviews.reviewText: I read the shipment of product doesn’t have anything to do with the review of product. In that case I’ll write a review of my past experience. My baby used the vanilla pacifiers from the hospital and does not like any other ones. They last and he uses them to teeth. I wash and throw in the steamer to sanitize. The vanilla scent dissipates after some time.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on April 10, 2023
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars Just like hospitals
reviews.reviewText: My baby ONLY likes the vanilla scented pacifiers like this. I looked in every store and couldn’t find them. Ordered on Amazon, and they sent the unscented ones. Then I found these…. They are the exact ones she likes!

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on March 12, 2017
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars The hospital said we couldn't buy these in vanilla scent. Challenge accepted I said.
reviews.reviewText: The nurse at the hospital told me that after I took my baby home from the hospital, I would not be able to buy the same type pacifier that they give us in the nursery. "Oh you can buy them like this, but they won't be vanilla scented like the ones we give the babies here in the nursery.""HA! Challenge accepted," I said with an evil grin. "I have Amazon prime. Excuse me while I whip this out..." Then the nurse gasped in horror as I reached into my pants and pulled out my iPhone and started fingering the screen. Within minutes I had ordered these apparently "hospital exclusive" pacifiers right from my ultra uncomfortable back-breaking couch in my wifes hospital room. "I'll have more on my doorstop before we even leave the hospital with the baby," I said with a seductive wink. The nurses face was flushed with heat as she embarrassingly left the room. She returned 5 minutes later with coffee for me that I didn't even ask for.
